title: Will Serbia and Kosovo reach a comprehensive normalization agreement  before 1 January 2020?
preds: The timeline is too short and there is not currently a compelling reason for either party to agree to a settlement on an expedited timeline.  Serbia will continue to negotiate and use its geography to extract maximum benefit from both Europe and Russia.  As a founding member of the Non-Aligned movement, Serbia understands the strategic geography and will commit to one side or the other only when absolutely necessary.

Normalization of Relations between Belgrade and Pristina – A Long Walk to Agreement

Paris meeting between the leaders of the two countries has been postponed, and the tariffs on goods from Serbia remain one of the biggest obstacles to renewing negotiations. Situation in the North of Kosovo remains unstable.
Aleksandar Vučić, Johannes Hahn and Hashim Thaci; Photo: Twitter / Munich Security Conference European Commission will not be able to resume full mediation before November, and the election of Josep Borell as the new High Representative has created some unease in Pristina due to Spain’s non-recognition of Kosovo’s independence. NB. THIS QUESTION CLOSES ONE YEAR BEFORE IT RESOLVES. (EDIT: Not any more). Although I'm not changing my forecast from my initial guess, I want to look into this further because I know nothing about this situation. So I'm making some summary notes here, all sourced from Wikipedia. Please comment if you spot any mistakes. KOSOVO
The Republic of Kosovo, capital Pristina, population about 2m, currency is the Euro. It is bounded by Albania, Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia. It declared independence from Serbia on 17 February 2008 but Serbia continues to claim that Kosovo remains part of Serbian territory and is blocking Kosovo's application to join the UN. It is a partially recognised state, being recognised by 111 UN countries but not by five of the 28 EU member states (Spain, Slovakia, Cyprus, Romania, and Greece) or by Serbia, Russia, or China. SERBIA
Serbia, capital Belgrade, population about 7m (excluding Kosovo), currency is the Serbian dinar. Serbia is a fully recognised state. Aleksandar Vučić became the 5th President of Serbia on 31 May 2017, appointing Ana Brnabić to replace him as Prime Minister, a post which he had held since 27 April 2014. Vučić has been central to negotiations on Serbia’s bid for EU accession. EUROPEAN UNION
The EU formally recognises Serbia, but not Kosovo. The European Parliament adopted a resolution on 8 July 2010 calling on all member states to recognise Kosovo. On 6 February 2018, the European Commission published its expansion plan to cover up to six Western Balkan countries: Albania, Bosnia & Herzegovina, Kosovo, Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Montenegro, and Serbia. Since 2007 the EU has maintained a permanent force of 2,000 personnel (including police officers, four anti-riot units, prosecutors and judges) in Kosovo. The level of EU influence in Kosovo has led some to term it an EU protectorate. INITIAL THOUGHTS
Serbian President Vučić wants EU accession. The EU will not allow that until relations between Serbia and Kosovo are normalised. Kosovo is extremely unlikely to agree to be part of Serbia, which means that in order to gain EU accession, Serbia must formally recognise Kosovo. TODO
1. Develop a baseline case.
2. Look into Serbian politics to determine how likely Serbia is to agree to recognise Kosovo. ONGOING EDITS

28 Dec 2018: Kosovo sets import tariffs on all goods from Serbia and Bosnia to 100% [2].
3 Jan 2019: Serbia suspends all exports to Kosovo [3].
4 Jan 2019: Kosovo’s team for negotiations with Serbia to visit Brussels next week [4].
6 Jan 2019: Serbian Foreign Minister Ivica Dacic doubts that the Kosovo issue will be resolved in 2019 [5].
7 Jan 2019: US offers to bring the leaders of Kosovo and Serbia together for a White House ceremony [6].
25 Feb 2019: Draft agreement leaked [7]. [1] https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/dec/14/kosovo-to-create-army-in-defiance-of-serbia-and-nato

When a country elects a president, the choice is not usually someone whose stated aim is to break it apart. But that’s just happened—ominously—in a country synonymous with 20th century European conflict. Milorad Dodik, who is emerging as the most powerful politician in Bosnia-Herzegovina after a vote this month, has made a career of advocating partition. He’s the leader of the Serb minority in that hyphenated country stitched together after the Balkan wars of the 1990s; and he’s always been clear about what he wants—to carve it up again and create an independent entity allied to Serbia next door. “This is not a common state, we are all its prisoners,” he said in 2016. “Bosnia isn’t worth a dime.”
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-10-19/the-balkans-are-coming-apart-at-the-seams-again?srnd=premium-asia

Although Serbia and Kosovo have both expressed a desire to join the EU, they are not likely to reach a comprehensive normalization agreement before 2020 because there are still high tensions between the countries, the actions implemented to ease the tensions are not aimed at the root of the conflict, and Russia's influence over Serbian politics and the economy. In Serbia and Kosovo, there are heavily nationalistic ideals which exacerbates tensions. This is especially true in places where there are still Serb villages in Kosovo, and people in Kosovo who identify as Serbs. Instead of creating programs that help to assimilate these populations and grow acceptance, they are seeking to redraw country border lines. This discussion does not signify a move towards normalization, but rather a discussion that could lead to increased tensions. Russia also has very close economic ties with Serbia, as they supply their oil, as well as cultural and religious ones. This aspect of their relations could deter Serbia from reaching a normalization, especially given that both Serbia and Russia refuse to recognize Kosovo as a country. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-08-18/russia-s-embrace-sows-total-confusion-for-serbia-s-eu-hopes https://wapo.st/2RoslQD?tid=ss_mail&utm_term=.9bfe4f5fb24d https://europeanwesternbalkans.com/2018/10/18/getting-agreement-serbia-kosovo/

“I am aware that the dialogue is very challenging. However, there are positive signals for building mutual trust. Both sides have secured Vučić’s arrival in Kosovo. It would be positive if the new round of dialogue continued in Brussels by the end of the month”, McAllister said. Asked about differences in positions of the sides in dialogue and international community on the possible content of the final solution, as well as date for reaching it, rapporteur for Serbia pointed out that it is Belgrade and Pristina who decide “on the topics and time-frame” of the negotiations, while EU is only facilitating the dialogue. “It is currently impossible to predict either content or date of a potential agreement”, McAllister stated.
https://europeanwesternbalkans.com/2018/09/11/mcallister-vucic-thaci-raised-normalisation-next-level/

Kosovo and Serbia tensions increased at the beginning of the year, leading to the two leaders to arrange a set of meetings. The major issue is the complexity of the normalization of relations. While I think a normalization of relations, is on the horizon ... the deadline of January 2020 is problematic, in the sense that potentially a new US President could be taking office that month, and the Kosovars may delay until the entry of a new administration. The EU has also made the balkans a priority this year during the Bulgarian and Austrian presidencies, but this orientation may not outlive the Austrian presidency. While the Balkans have seen major developments over the last 12 months, for example Macedonia and Greece cooperating over the name change, this may not domino into the wider region.  Nevertheless a political motivation from both Pristina and Belgrade seems to be there that was not in the past, which leads me to wager that there is a 1/3 chance that this normalization is coming in the next 12-18 months.

As of now, there is constant back and forth between Serbia and Kosovo regarding normalization. The EU has made it clear to both countries that normalization in relations is a crucial act if the two desires to enter the EU.  Although this has been seen as a clear tool to persuade both parties, the situation is much more complex. Ethnic tensions are very high as Serbian officials and the general Serbian population refuse to acknowledge Kosovo as a sovereign nation. It’s been over 10 years since Kosovo declared independence and almost 20 years since the end of the War in Kosovo and there has been little success in normalization of the relationship between the two countries. Meetings that have thus far been planned have either been canceled or ended with little to no progress. The EU membership has been a good incentive for the two countries to begin working together, but current solutions that are being thrown around include a land swap, which has faced criticism from the international community as well as people in the region. If they continue with this solution at the rate they currently are, there is a very low chance that normalization will occur, however, if other solutions are proposed, and the two come to terms with the past, there is a chance for better success. Chances now are a bit better than they would have been 10 years ago, but still, the situation continues to slowly progress.  https://www.reuters.com/article/us-serbia-kosovo-eu/serbia-kosovo-leaders-abruptly-cancel-eu-brokered-meeting-on-land-swap-idUSKCN1LN1SD
http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/serbia-kosovo-meeting-ends-without-progress-07-18-2018
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/sep/03/us-backed-kosovo-land-swap-border-plan-under-fire-from-all-sides
Serbia's dragging feet and Kosovo's frustrations have roots which are growing deeper. Russia has special reasons to disrupt any real change.

Frustration over the process has led Kosovo to consider unilateral actions instead of normalization agreement. Larger players in the region (including Russia) have a vested interest in not recognizing the cessation of Kosovo.

Normalization between Serbia and Kosovo is a proxy political and geographical struggle between the Russia and the West.  The West prefers good relations between the two countries and Russia prefers mild instability causing the prevention of EU accession for both countries.  Keeping the two countries out of the EU is likely very important to Russia and contributing to poor relations is a good opportunity to prevent Western expansion.  If your country uses the Cyrillic alphabet, Russia wants you off of the West's roster of member states of the EU or NATO.  Prevention of accession only requires light to medium instability, whereas EU accession requires complete stability.  Helping to maintain discord between two countries that already dislike each other requires much less investment from Russia with a higher likelihood of favorable results.
Can they grow up and let bygones be bygones?  Will they be accepted to EU anyway? What's their economy like? Not that it stopped Italy or Greece joining with so much debt.

Despite the pressure on Serbia to come to a comprehensive agreement, there are several reasons why it's highly unlikely to happen before 2020:
- Serbia is willing to trade Kosovo's recognition in exchange for the entry into the EU. This one, however, will not occur before 2025. To give its bargaining chip that early would expose Serbia to the risk of not becoming an EU member state in 2025 for different reasons independent of its own will (refugee crisis, EU crisis, enlargement fatigue, another exit, and so on) and despite an earlier Kosovo recognition
- to recognize Kosovo at an acceptable cost, Serbia needs to obtain something from Pristina. This has not happened so far and in Pristina, they consider the case closed and see no reason why they should accept any compromise, which would oblige them to concessions
- for Pristina, the absence of a comprehensive agreement is a long-term problem (it will complicate its path toward NATO and EU) but this path still has a long way to go before any accomplishment is made
- the EU and the US have other problems to deal with than Balkans. This situation leads to a lack of interest and a diminished pressure on Belgrade and Pristina to find a compromise
- Russia has long been absent from the Balkans and any NATO enlargement in the Balkans would not have the same impact in Moscow as in the case of Ukraine Georgia or Moldova. As a result, atlanticists cannot play that card to push for an agreement between Belgrade and Pristina
- other "frozen conflicts" have not been resolved although they date from earlier times (Transniestria, Cyprus)
- there's always a small risk of opening the Pandorra box in the Balkans with the unstable situation in Bosnia, obliging the US and EU to move carefully and not provoke a too strong counter-reaction (that could be used by Russia to pursue its interests in the Balkans), diminishing the rush to a negotiated agreement that is totally detrimental for Serbia.
And if  Greece and Northern Macedonia can work things out...why not.

If Serbia wants to submit the European Union, they have to make a progress on that question. But the fronts are very hardened.

The Kosovar daily Gazeta Express, quoting a political advisor to the president of Kosovo, reports that the final round of normalization talks between Kosovo and Serbia should start at the end of June and are expected to last until mid-2019. On the Serb side, President Aleksandar Vucic acknowledged that uphill battle facing him, noting that "Polls shows that 80 percent of Serbia is in favor of frozen conflict." Nevertheless, he has stated his intention to convince the people of Serbia to accept an agreement, even if its political suicide: "I will do my best, with no regard for my political career, to overcome that attitude. I will not make a decision against our people, but will seek to convince a majority of the people that peace and stability are more important to us than anything else." http://m.gazetaexpress.com/en/mobile/news/eu-wants-kosovo-serbia-dialogue-to-start-in-june-says-blerim-shala-174140/ https://www.b92.net/eng/news/politics.php?yyyy=2018&mm=05&dd=25&nav_id=104244

The key issue is Serbia's perception of what Kosovo is and should be. Any normalization process is going to require key compromise on Pec and Mitrovica  at the very least and agreement on specific sites holding Serbian sovereignty or being under international jurisdiction. This seems unlikely.
We are in a situation that the EU (germany & France) can show some leadership and get something of meaning done! As of now it is a 2/3 for the no!

News reports out of Belgrade continue to suggest that Prime Minister Vuvic may call a referendum on any future agreement recognizing Kosovo, despite Western objections. The Serbian constitution includes a special section mentioning that Kosovo is an integral part of Serbian territory and Serb nationalists believe Kosovo is the cradle of their civilization and the birthplace of the Serbian Orthodox Church. A survey conducted at the end of last year concluded that while Serbs don't wish to give up on Kosovo, they don't want to sacrifice their a future in the EU over the issue. The same survey showed only 7% of Serbs believe Kosovar independence is the "best solution," while 20% believe Kosovo "will become an independent state regardless of the effort of Serbia and that Serbia will lose all influence in Kosovo.”  In an interview with the Financial Times, Vucic stated "I’m obsessed with Kosovo. Without resolving that problem everything I have achieved so far won’t be sustainable. The first crisis will kill us.” Given the tenacity of Serbian nationalism, resistance from the church, and the near certainty of Russian meddling, a referendum seems unlikely to pass, especially without a guarantee of autonomy or outright partition for Serb-majority northern Kosovo. Although on the other hand, the FT article notes that "Mr Vucic could still prevail in a referendum, given his political dominance and grip on the media." http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/serbia-between-referendum-and-elections-over-kosovo-05-17-2018 https://www.ft.com/content/286fadc4-5444-11e8-b3ee-41e0209208ec

Serbian nationalists are in the process of the collecting signatures for a referendum to block any normalization agreement between the Serbian government and Kosovo. They hope to collect the required 100k signatures by June 28.
http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/new-serbian-initiative-for-referendum-for-kosovo-launched-05-03-2018 Meanwhile, European Council President Donald Tusk stated: "Without a comprehensive normalization of relations with Serbia and full implementation of the agreements, I don't see how a breakthrough in relations with the EU could be achieved." Although he added that he was "cautiously optimistic" an agreement can be reached. 
https://www.rferl.org/amp/eu-president-tusk-urges-kosovo-serbia-work-hard-normalizing-relations-join-eu-integration/29195097.html

Potential Scenarios
--------------------
1) Full mutual formal recognition
2) De facto mutual recognition that stops short of formal recognition
3) Maintaining the status quo
4) Deterioration of the situation into hostility or war Influencing factors
---------------------
1) Nationalistic governments in Pristina and Belgrade
2) EU pressure to reach an agreement
3) Pressure from Russia on Serbia
4) Kosovar Establishment of Serbian Association of Municipalities autonomous area in northern Kosovo (ZSO) per 2013 agreement
5) Incidents, such as the assassination of Kosovo Serb leader Oliver Ivanovic in March of this year that fans the flames of nationalistic sentiment
6) The possibility of partitioning Kosovo so the northern territories are ceded to Serbia in exchange for Albanian enclaves on Serb territory
7) Serbia's willingness to allow Kosovo to join international organizations  Key Facts
----------------
1) Kosovo claims they will set up the ZSO within 4 months
2) According to a survey by the Institute for European Affairs, 50% of Serbs think Kosovo is lost but 80% would choose regaining Kosovo over joining the EU
3) Formal recognition of Kosovo would require a referendum as it would change the constitution  
4) Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic has stated on April 25th that an agreement is not imminent and the two sides are far apart
5) Vucic also believes an agreement could be reached within 6 months to a year. He has stated he wants benefits from Serbia in exchange (not sure if he means from the EU or from Kosovo) as well as an agreement that won't "humiliate" Serbia
6) Kosovar president Hashim Thaçi has also stated he expects a comprehensive agreement to be reached by the end of the year Key Assumptions
-----------------
1) Vucic is a strong enough leader to sell an agreement to the Serbian people and counter Russian influence
2) Russia would view Serbia's ascension to the EU as against its regional interests and would make some effort to thwart an agreement as it did in Montenegro's elections
3) Hashim Thaçi is able to sell an agreement to the Kosovar people and his government
4) The EU would be willing to settle on a mostly comprehensive agreement that does not include full formal diplomatic recognition but instead recognizes Pristina's authority over Kosovar territory in order for both Serbia and Kosovo to proceed with their EU candidacies 
5) The EU will not collapse in the next year or so and will continue to maintain pressure on the two sides and EU accession will remain an attractive future to both. 
6) Kosovo will carry through on its obligation to establish the ZSO
7) There is growing doubt among the Serbian people about whether they will actually be allowed to join the EU at the end of the day and whether those ambitions are still worthwhile  Conclusion
-----------
The possibility of some sort of agreement within a year is quite high, but the question is: will it be a "comprehensive" agreement that includes full diplomatic recognition? Given the circumstances a near-comprehensive agreement that includes de facto recognition, obviates Serbian "humiliation" and resolves most of the key sticking points seems somewhat more likely at this juncture

Although it looks like it hasn't gone anywhere, these things can turn around. At them moment there are a lot of issues for them to work out. "For almost 1,800 days, the six main points [on Serb municipalities] remain untouched," Vucic told Serbian TV. He also cast blame on the European Union for not enforcing the 2013 agreement. But, there is a desire from both sides to fix this problem. Thaci said the most important thing was that both Kosovo and Serbia want to reach an agreement. "The agreement on full normalization is seen as a very difficult thing, but it is the only way forward," he said. Mogherini in a statement after the talks stressed that a comprehensive normalization agreement between two countries is a key condition for both countries to further their bids to join the EU. The EU is pushing for completion of the normalization agreement by the end of 2019. This statement seems to be the real hang up. 
Kosovo declared independence in 2008, but Serbia has refused to recognize the former province's statehood despite its recognition by 116 other countries. It sounds a lot like Palestine and Israel, but I'm not sure it's to the same degree. For now I believe it's possible that an agreement will be reached. It will depend on crucial an EU member is for the two countries. I'll research this now, but I'm leaning that it will happen.

An agreement of some kind, yes.  A comprehensive one?  Nope.

It is unlikely that Serbia and Kosovo will reach a comprehensive normalization agreement before 1 January 2020. Relations between Serbia and Kosovo are extremely tense and there has been little effort from officials on either side to fix the relationship between the two countries. While both countries are hoping to join the EU in the future, I don't see either side spearheading a normalization agreement anytime soon. Serbia is still phasing out institutions from the Kosovo war (http://emerging-europe.com/in-brief/serbia-kosovo-tensions-rise/), and until both sides feel like they have received reparations and reconciliation, there will be little progress in a normalization agreement. Additionally, the EU has set a path for possible accession of some Balkans nations in the year 2025, so while I see the probability of an agreement increasing with time, a normalization agreement by the end of 2019 is extremely unlikely. http://prishtinainsight.com/kosovo-serbia-normalization-agreement-key-benchmark-eu-accession/ timeframe
We need more time in relationhip between Serbia and Kosovo.

Serbia, in order to stay on track to join the EU, has to at least begin normalization with Kosovo. Entrance into the EU could reboot the struggling Serbian economy and spark reform in a nation still badly broken by the ethnic wars of the 1990's. Reluctance on the part of Belgrade in part is due to its need "to  reform its slow and unwieldy judiciary, improve rule of law, tackle the freedoms of the media and safeguard minority rights" as well as improve their relations with other Balkan states such as Bosnia and Croatia. The EU, still reeling from Brexit, may accept the beginnings of normalization as "progress," in hopes to balance the loss of Britain.

Not sure what Russia/VVP thinks/doesn't think about this is hugely important. As long as Belgrade wants EU membership, they will have to find some way around normalisation. The EU membership has value in a number of ways to Serbia, including economically (http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/kosovo-territory-swap-would-net-serbia-90-million-study-04-20-2018), and is relatively politically popular (https://www.euractiv.com/section/enlargement/news/most-serbs-support-eu-membership-cite-job-opportunities-in-new-poll/).  Normalisation is obviously a big step for Pristina as well​ if they hope to get on the EU track. The low estimate comes from the timeframe. Serbia has only closed two chapters of the 35 acquis communautaire so far. Earliest accession date is 2025, and that's theoretical, so there seems to be no huge rush to finally solve the hardest thing immediately. There is a lot of room to continue making progress on an agreement without finalising one, which gives a lot of time to drip feed the ideas to the various stakeholders, which is probably preferable to a headlong political lunge. It's hard to see then how we get from where we are now to a signed agreement in about 20 months.  It's not zero, because Thaci has made noises on the importance of pushing ahead in 2018, and subsequently Kosovo is supposed to be drafting a Statute on the ZSO (Serb municipalities) by the summer (https://eeas.europa.eu/headquarters/headquarters-homepage/42518/statement-spokesperson-announced-drafting-statute-associationcommunity-serb-majority_en,https://www.b92.net/eng/news/politics.php?yyyy=2018&mm=04&dd=19&nav_id=103970). I'll look again and revise if they come up with something within the timeframe that is acceptable to Belgrade.
